title: The hidden whack behind Ange’s wild selection
text:
ANALYSIS: Twist of fate for Rogic spot 
It is also a call to action to fellow youngsters by showing that opportunities beckon for this brave enough to put their names forward. 
“You want to see (youngsters) – part of football worldwide is the excitement of young players breaking through,” Postecoglou said on Tuesday. 
“You’d like to think we’d get half a dozen a year (break through) but we haven’t really. 
“Obviously in our competition, there’s limited opportunities - with the season being so condensed the ability to give a player an extended run (is not there). 
“Maybe in the case of some young players we wait too long ... We need to throw them in earlier. 
“It’s tough in our league. 
“I have to do what I preach - if a young player shows something special I’m not going to wait too long to expose them in the national team and encourage them. No McGree, it's not a joke 0:49 
“Particularly with young players – between age 18-21 - they don’t play enough senior football and in many respects that destroys many carers or hampers ability to play higher level. 
“Unfortunately that’s the space we’re in. 
“For my perspective, I’ve had my radar up for a while to give a young kid an opportunity. 
“I’ve done it in the past, (for example) with Daniel De Silva, but they’ve suffered from a lack of game time. 
“Hopefully Riley’s (selection) means … maybe Adelaide will give him an extended run and others in a similar age group start hopefully people take things more seriously. 
“It’s about ambition, I don’t want people who are going to settle for their lot because of an age bracket – I’m looking for guys who want to grab it and I want to incentivise that.” 
Last week, Postecoglou foreshadowed that McGree’s selection in the 30 was not a token. 
He has threatened that again after he made the cut again. 
“No, he’s there to contribute. If he does well at training he can play … if he looks like he’s adjusted well at training and looks bright we won’t be afraid to throw him in either.” 
More realistically, he is there to be examined, and to send a message, and the timing of this camp is the best opportunity for that to happen given the A-League is finished by the time the Brazil match rolls around. Riley McGree of Adelaide United. Source: AAP 
“I’ve never felt the need to sit on these things if there’s somebody there to have a look at I’ll bring them in,” he explained. 
“In the past I feel we’ve waited too long 
“We’ll give him an opportunity and see how he adapts to the environment 
“If it proves a good move he could be an exciting one for years to come.” 
What was it exactly that prompted the surprising selection? 
“There’s a whole range of things, for me the biggest thing is for an 18-year-old he has stepped in and looked the part. 
“He is exciting when he runs with the ball - one of these players with the ability to excite. 
“All those types of things will be measured and tested at the highest possible level now. 
“For now, for me, I see it as a young player coming into our league and he’s already made an impression. 
“From my perspective there’s a few attributes I’d like to look at.” View All Comments The latest sports news, in your inbox daily. Email
